analyzeResult.content:
DEAR PRESIDENT
CLINTON,
THE NETHERLANDS THANKS YOU
FOR YOUR FDA.
For that matter, so does the rest of Europe.
Because of our own Food and Drug Administra- tion's undue delays and overregulation, dozens of America's top medical and health care companies are moving operations to Europe.
They're moving jobs and investment abroad, But more importantly, they're moving the world's top medical and health care products- - advances that could save lives how in the U.S., if only the FDA could operate more efficiently.
For example:
FDA's former General Counsel, who is now in private law practice, stated in the November 4, 1994 edition of In- vestor's Business Daily: "I send at least one company a weck abroad. They're not going to get a fair shake here."
According to a 1993 U.S. Congress investigative report on the FDA, 49 medical devices tied up in red tape were then available in Europe. Over half were life-sustaining car- diovascular devices.
Minnesota medical device maker Medtronic announced on November 22, 1994 that it would move its Corporate Ventures group to the Netherlands, "to take advantage of a more favorable environment for medical innovation." Its CEO said, "A Medtronic product available in Europe in 1994 won't be available in this country until the year 2000."
The CEO of Minntech Corporation, which recently laid
off high-tech medical device workers in the U.S. while ex- panding in Europe, said in the Star Tribune, "The attitude of the FDA is so antibusiness and so negative at this point that any prudent CEO has to be looking outside the U.S. for a safe haven."
ABC's 20/20, in a program on the FDA, reported: "In a :selected: recent survey of America's medical device makers, 45% said they do intend to leave this country."
We all want safe, effective, carefully tested medicines and treatments. But let's have them in our lifetime . .. not long after we've died in agony from a disease other nations have controlled for years.
For more information, please contact: The WI.F Health Care Project, Washington Legal Foundation, 2009 Mass- achusetts Ave., N.W., Washington, DC 20036. And of course, please feel free to reprint this message without permission.
52260 8652
THE PROBLEM WITH HEALTH CARE IN AMERICA IS THE FDA
AG BEEN IN ROLL CALL :selected: :selected:

paragraphs.content: For that matter, so does the rest of Europe.
Because of our own Food and Drug Administra- tion's undue delays and overregulation, dozens of America's top medical and health care companies are moving operations to Europe.

They're moving jobs and investment abroad, But more importantly, they're moving the world's top medical and health care products- - advances that could save lives how in the U.S., if only the FDA could operate more efficiently.

FDA's former General Counsel, who is now in private law practice, stated in the November 4, 1994 edition of In- vestor's Business Daily: "I send at least one company a weck abroad. They're not going to get a fair shake here."
According to a 1993 U.S. Congress investigative report on the FDA, 49 medical devices tied up in red tape were then available in Europe. Over half were life-sustaining car- diovascular devices.

Minnesota medical device maker Medtronic announced on November 22, 1994 that it would move its Corporate Ventures group to the Netherlands, "to take advantage of a more favorable environment for medical innovation." Its CEO said, "A Medtronic product available in Europe in 1994 won't be available in this country until the year 2000."
The CEO of Minntech Corporation, which recently laid

off high-tech medical device workers in the U.S. while ex- panding in Europe, said in the Star Tribune, "The attitude of the FDA is so antibusiness and so negative at this point that any prudent CEO has to be looking outside the U.S. for a safe haven."
ABC's 20/20, in a program on the FDA, reported: "In a :selected: recent survey of America's medical device makers, 45% said they do intend to leave this country."

We all want safe, effective, carefully tested medicines and treatments. But let's have them in our lifetime . .. not long after we've died in agony from a disease other nations have controlled for years.

For more information, please contact: The WI.F Health Care Project, Washington Legal Foundation, 2009 Mass- achusetts Ave., N.W., Washington, DC 20036. And of course, please feel free to reprint this message without permission.
